reviewText: SECRETS OF CHRISTIANITY (2011 for The History Channel, 270 minutes total) is a spectacular documetary series I must defend - not just because it is brilliant and my quasi-colleague Simcha Jacobovici is responsible - but because it is truly a work of depth and a documentary worth its salt.In short, this series by investigative journalist/documentarist Simcha Jacobovici addresses some issues in the history of Christianity. As I have stated in my review of Simcha's work onThe Lost Tomb of Jesusand other related projects, I am concerned about his eagerness to hitch his wagon to the New Testament. I am concerned that he and 'partner in crime', the great Professor James Tabor of North Carolina, want the early Christian community to have been 100% Jewish ... which is an asinine proposition.Unless "christian" meant something else in the past.Simcha is here to peel back the layers of the past, of history and of truth, to shed light on the first Christians and their mysteries. He kicks off by wondering if the famous sea voyage undertaken by Jesus and disciples was a voyage all the way to present-day Cádiz, Spain. Simcha travels there and with a typical hunch he finds a Converso community that claims it is related to Jesus by blood.This series begins with that and a stunning eye-opener of a revelation: there was a Jewish precedent for the ideas surrounding the Christian version of Jesus. Around the time of Jesus' birth, there was a fellow named Shimon of Perea (which is in Jordan whence came some of Jesus' cousins). Shimon was a Jewish leader, a revolutionary dedicated to whipping the Romans.Simcha reveals how this Shimon was actually crowned king, accepted as Messiah - and when the Romans beheaded him, the 'resurrection' cult was born. Imagine that! Jesus was following an already established Jewish cult, and it centered around the bodily resurrection of a messiah-king. And they called him "SIMONOS CHRISTOS" in Greek! His followers called themselves "christianos"!Not only did it "sound familiar". That fact right there answered almost all of my lifelong, burning queries. Simcha elegantly and effortlessly shows how old Shimon was the original Christ, while Jesus got turned into a version of Mithras by the pagans who we now know as Christians. Stunning.Some of the other mysteries Simcha explores are the ossuarium of the High Priest Caiaphas (to see if it is true that crucifixion nails were entombed with him); sets off for Herculaneum and surrounding areas to see whether Jewish slaves there actually brought Christianity into their midst just before the volcano blew (I am discomfited by this because I don't see why a Jew of that time HAS to also be a "Christian" which Simcha loves to nag about); he trots about Italy and other places examining things like the "Sator" square, a magic acrostic square that early Roman military Christians used as a prayer amulet.Simcha dissects Constantine's phony conversion to Christianity, further exposing the modern Christian faith as almost totally Constantine-created. As Simcha indicates, Constantin worshipped one son of God: himself, Son of the Sun God.Finally, Simcha and crew are off again, trying to see whether ancient graffiti at Pompeii helps bolster his theory that "Judaeo-Christianity" was spread rapidly and faithfully across the world before 79 A.D. The volcanic eruption, it is posited here, may have been responsible for tens of thousands of conversions to Judaism and Christianity before 100 A.D. Again, it is insisted here that this proves a "true Judeao-Christian" community in those days.I say why couldn't it be pagans who took Jewish names? Everyone else was pagan, and the Jews were not about to suddenly leap off the cliff of a completely new, mostly poorly invented religion, or join a pagan cult! What Jacobovici and Tabor truly start revealing here, however, is a Jewish survival mechanism I love: the "Jewish Pope" phenomenon, as I call it. The intrepid pair here discover that the Jews were actively head-hunting for Messiahs to crown. Anything to fight Rome.And suddenly it all makes sense. What Simcha finds and explains will surprise, astonish and move you deeply. This man, unlike most everyone else, is not looking for convenient facts to prove the New Testament.He is looking for THE TRUTH - and they are two entirely different things. Hooray for Simcha Jacobovici and his commitment to excellent documentary work, exploration, and science. Look out for the not-so-unusual section when Simcha is examining an artifact and actually discovers secrets right in front of the experts who never noticed them before. So typical of him. This self-labeled "journalist" is one of the luckiest and most persistent men alive.This is a highly recommended work and its price is excellent. Why people hate Simcha and his work is really beyond me, but after I read the only other review of this so far, I think I am beginning to see the light. People don't like Simcha because he seeks TRUTH, not New Testament platitudes. After all, he is Jewish.

reviewText: The 411:Did Jesus travel by boat to the Land of Gadarene? In the first part of the DVD, we head to Gadarene where investigators inspect a boat located and believed to be the boat that Jesus and the Disciples traveled in.  This is where it gets good. We see a replica boat, people aboard as the journalists asks if it is possible for Jesus to have slept while on this trip. The story obviously has holes as the archeologist explains what a moment aboard the ship would have been like. There would be no sleeping during a "tempest". This sets the mood for the rest of the DVD that goes on todebunking various moments of the bible.  Real experiments done using real locations in the bible.We all want to believe in the words of the bible. What the segment does is try establish truth in the historical words that millions believe in. As someone with limited knowledge of the details in the bible I believe that the world was different then. They kept talking about the sea being very far from the location of Gadara but I believe as one of the Archaeologists says, it is a miracle and we can't pinpoint and scrutinize every single word.While I appreciate the well made documentary, I refuse to believe that everything CAN be explained.  What annoyed me the most about this documentary was the smug face Simcha Jacobovici uses when he feels he has established inconsistencies.The DVD for me was very controversial. It felt very bias and as if I was being spoon fed theories of  Simcha.
Title: Secrets Of Christianity
